awd_titl_txt: The 2023 ICLDC: Building infrastructure for achieving justice in Language Documentation & Conservation
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Conference on Language Documentation and Conservation (ICLDC) has become a central meeting for research on language documentation and conservation, which brings together leading researchers, students, and community members around the important science of language documentation. The 2023 ICLDC offers its highly-diverse audience opportunities for formal and informal science education and training that includes new methodologies and best practices in cutting-edge language documentation and that crosses traditional disciplinary boundaries. Participants include undergraduate students, graduate students and faculty from linguistics, anthropology, biology, computer science, and other academic disciplines. ICLDC has also included a large number of citizen scientists from historically underrepresented groups in the sciences, such as Native Americans, Native Alaskans, Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, offering opportunities for broadening participation in the language sciences as one of the broader impacts of this conference.

In addition to its other crucial scientific benefits, research in language documentation and conservation has the potential to increase awareness of and interest in a greater emphasis on justice in research in the language sciences. Justice goals have always been central to community-based and community-led language work, even if they have not always been primary among goals for academic linguistics. By bringing together stakeholders from multiple areas in the language sciences, the special theme of the 2023 ICLDC aims to normalize the idea that linguists have social responsibilities that extend beyond the strictly linguistic. The International Decade of Indigenous Languages presents an opportune time for the field of language documentation and conservation to develop a disciplinary framework that establishes justice as both the starting point and end goals of this work. The field of linguistics has not yet held an international conversation on achieving justice within language documentation and conservation, what role language workers play in achieving justice in intersecting realms, and how justice can critically inform, and reform, best practices in language documentation and conservation work. The 2023 ICLDC is a venue for this critical and timely conversation, providing a key opportunity for practitioners to build relationships and develop the social infrastructure necessary for working toward a justice-driven model of language work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since its inception in 2009, the ICLDC has been the flagship conference of the field of language documentation and conservation, becoming a forum for highlighting successes, identifying and working through challenges, and creating collaborations and models for best practice. The theme of ICLDC 8 in 2023 was "Centering Justice in Language Work", and the aim was to provide a venue in which stakeholders could critically reassess the role that language documentation and conservation play with respect to justice writ large. The conference ultimately included 140+ papers, posters, workshops, Talk Stories, and plenaries related to this theme. Engagement with the justice-related theme was enthusiastic among our attendees. We expect that the important discussions about justice in language work which began at ICLDC 8 will continue at both a local and a field-wide level in the coming years, and that published papers, interdisciplinary collaborations, and projects in language work rooted in justice goals will be produced as a result.

Issues of social justice affecting speakers and language communities are not just linguistic. There is a growing body of research showing that linguistic justice intersects with other areas in which justice is lacking, including the environmental, health, legal, political, economic, and educational realms. This was reflected in the wide variety of papers and posters at ICLDC 8 exploring linguistic justice from the perspective of education, pedagogy, political science, musicology, ethnobotany, sociology, and other fields. We believe that ICLDC 8 brought to global prominence the interdisciplinary nature of justice work, which is readily apparent at the local level in community language work.

The many language teachers, students, and community-based language workers who attended ICLDC were able to exchange knowledge, brainstorm ideas, and create collaborations related to language documentation and conservation during the conference through attending paper and poster presentations, workshops, talk stories, and the He 'Ōlelo Ola Field Study in Hilo, HI. Recordings of the paper presentations and PDFs of the posters are publicly available on our ICLDC 8 YouTube channel and the Kaipuleohone Archive, respectively, ensuring that the public has access to the ideas shared at ICLDC 8 going forward.

In keeping with the theme of "Centering Justice in Language Work", ICLDC 8 was held virtually in order to increase access to the conference to all who are engaged in community-oriented language work, and to lessen its ecological impact and the economic burden on attendees.

For ICLDC 8, we welcomed a total of 660 registrants from 43 countries representing every inhabited continent, including group registrations for Tribal community members and class groups. The conference featured over 140 paper and poster presentations, Workshops, and Talk Story sessions in addition to two plenary talks, social mixers, and a film screening. ICLDC once again partnered with He 'Õlelo Ola Field Study in Hilo, and ICLDC attendees had the opportunity to attend that. Due to the sheer scale and scope of the conference, the ideas shared at ICLDC 8 had much wider dissemination than what would have been possible had we held the conference in person. By promoting equity in attendance and participation, we have moved discussions of justice-oriented approaches to language work from the local/regional to the global scale.
